snippet.title: A $100,000 salary doesn't put you in the top 1% of income at any age
snippet.content:
A lot of people are overjoyed to cross the $US100,000 threshold in annual income. And they should be - a six-figure salary is nothing to sneeze at.
But as income inequality in the US , a $US100,000 salary creeps ever-closer to being an upper-middle-class income, not a sure sign of wealth.
In fact, according to a Business Insider analysis of US Census data, the $US100,000 distinction isn't enough to put anyone, at any age for which there is reliable data, in the top 1% of personal incomes.
Here is the full breakdown.
Business Insider analysed data from the , an annual survey by the US Census Bureau that talks to 1% of all US households about various economic, social, and housing demographics.
Specifically, we used individual-level data from the , a project of the Minnesota Population Center at the University of Minnesota, which allowed us to estimate the cutoffs for being in the top 1% of earners among for each age in 2015.
Ultimately, the data showed $US116,000 at age 25 was the smallest six-figure salary you could have in order to be in the top 1% relative to your peers. But that number quickly jumps to $US200,000 by the time you reach your 30s and $US300,000 by the time you pass 35.
